Fitting with Different Loss and Link Functions

Source: vignettes/loss_and_links.Rmd
loss_and_links.Rmd
library(SensIAT)

Introduction

In this framework let A=aA=a denote the treatment arm, YY the outcome variable, and tt the time variable. The SensIAT package allows users to specify different loss functions and link functions when fitting models to their data. This flexibility enables users to tailor the modeling approach to their specific research questions and data characteristics. Let Î¼a(t)=E{Y(t)âˆ£A=a}\mu_a(t) = E\{Y(t)\mid A=a\} denote the population mean outcome at time tt were all participants assigned to treatment arm A=aA=a. The mean function is modeled as $_a(t) = g{-1}((t)_a) = s((t)^_a) $ where gg is a link function, ğ\mathbf{B} is a vector values basis function and Î³a\gamma_a is a vector of coefficients, distinct for each treatment arm. The function s=gâˆ’1s = g^{-1} is the inverse link function. We consider three loss functions to use in order to fit the coefficient Î³a\gamma_a:

  • â„’1(ğ›„)=âˆ«t=t1t2[g{Î¼(t)}âˆ’ğ(t)â€²ğ›„]2dt\mathcal{L}_1(\boldsymbol{\gamma}) = \int_{t=t_1}^{t_2} \left[ g\left\{\mu(t)\right\} - \boldsymbol{B}(t)^\prime \boldsymbol{\gamma}\right]^2 dt, squared error loss in the transformed space;
  • â„’2(ğ›„)=âˆ«t=t1t2[Î¼(t)âˆ’s{ğ(t)â€²ğ›„}]2dt\mathcal{L}_2(\boldsymbol{\gamma}) = \int_{t=t_1}^{t_2} \left[ \mu(t) - s\left\{\boldsymbol{B}(t)^\prime \boldsymbol{\gamma}\right\}\right]^2 dt, squared error loss in the original space;
  • â„’3(ğ›„)=âˆ«t=t1t2[b{ğ(t)â€²ğ›„}âˆ’Î¼(t)ğ(t)â€²ğ›„]dt\mathcal{L}_3(\boldsymbol{\gamma}) = \int_{t=t_1}^{t_2} \left[ b\{\boldsymbol{B}(t)^\prime \boldsymbol{\gamma}\} - \mu(t)\boldsymbol{B}(t)^\prime \boldsymbol{\gamma}\right] dt, quasi-likelihood loss, where s(z)=âˆ‚b(z)âˆ‚zs(z) = \frac{\partial b(z)}{\partial z }. In the SensIAT package, we have implemented the following link functions:
  • Identity link: g(Î¼)=Î¼g(\mu) = \mu, s(z)=zs(z) = z,
  • Log link: g(Î¼)=log(Î¼)g(\mu) = \log(\mu), s(z)=exp(z)s(z) = \exp(z),
  • Logit link: g(Î¼)=log(Î¼1âˆ’Î¼)g(\mu) = \log\left(\frac{\mu}{1-\mu}\right), s(z)=exp(z)1+exp(z)s(z) = \frac{\exp(z)}{1+\exp(z)}.

Fitting with Different Loss and Link Functions

The estimate for the treatment group marginal mean function, Î¼Ì‚â„’,g(t)=gâˆ’1{ğ(t)â€²ğ›ƒÌ‚}\widehat\mu_{\mathcal{L}, g}(t) = g^{-1}\big\{\boldsymbol{B}(t)^\prime \widehat{\boldsymbol{\beta}}\big\} is found by solving 1nâˆ‘i=1nğš¿Ì‚â„’,g(ği;ğ›ƒ)=0\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^n \widehat{\boldsymbol{\Psi}}_{\mathcal{L},g}(\boldsymbol{O}_i;\boldsymbol{\beta}) = 0, for Î²\beta, where

ğš¿Ì‚j(ği;ğ›ƒ)=âˆ‘k=1Ki{Wâ„’,g(Tik;ğ›ƒ)[Yi(Tik)âˆ’ğ”¼Ì‚{Y(Tik)âˆ£ğÂ¯i(Tik)}]ÏÌ‚{Tikâˆ£ğÂ¯i(Tik),Yi(Tik)}}+âˆ«t=t1t2Wâ„’,g(tâˆ£ğ›ƒ)[ğ”¼Ì‚{Y(t)âˆ£ğÂ¯i(t)}âˆ’s{ğ(t)â€²ğ›ƒ}]dt \widehat{\boldsymbol{\Psi}}_j(\boldsymbol{O}_i;\boldsymbol{\beta}) = \sum_{k=1}^{K_i} \Bigg\{ W_{\mathcal{L}, g}(T_{ik};\boldsymbol{\beta})\frac{\big[Y_i(T_{ik}) - \widehat{\mathbb{E}} \big\{Y(T_{ik}) \mid \overline{\boldsymbol{O}}_i(T_{ik}) \big\} \big] }{\widehat{\rho} \big \{T_{ik} \mid \overline{\boldsymbol{O}}_i(T_{ik}), Y_i(T_{ik}) \big\}} \Bigg\} + \int_{t=t_1}^{t_2} W_{\mathcal{L}, g}(t\mid\boldsymbol{\beta}) \left[ \widehat{\mathbb{E}} \left\{ Y(t)\mid \overline{\boldsymbol{O}}_i(t) \right\} - s\left\{ \boldsymbol{B}(t)^\prime \boldsymbol{\beta} \right\} \right]dt The Wâ„’,g(t;ğ›ƒ)W_{\mathcal{L}, g}(t;\boldsymbol{\beta}) term depends on the choice of loss function and link function.

Details

Squared Error Loss in the Transformed Space

For squared error loss in the transformed space, â„’1\mathcal{L}_1, in general we have Wâ„’,g(t;ğ›ƒ)=W1(t;ğ›ƒ)=ğ•1âˆ’1ğ(t)âˆ‚g(z)âˆ‚z|z=s{ğ(t)â€²ğ›ƒ},ğ•1=âˆ«t=t1t2ğ(t)ğ(t)â€²dt W_{\mathcal{L},g}(t;\boldsymbol{\beta}) = W_1(t;\boldsymbol{\beta}) = \boldsymbol{V}_1^{-1}\boldsymbol{B}(t)\left.\frac{\partial g(z)}{\partial z} \right|_{z = s\left\{\boldsymbol{B}(t)^\prime \boldsymbol{\beta}\right\}} , \quad \boldsymbol{V}_1 = \int_{t=t_1}^{t_2} \boldsymbol{B}(t) \boldsymbol{B}(t)^\prime dt

Identity Link

For the identity link, g(Î¼)=Î¼g(\mu) = \mu, âˆ‚g(z)âˆ‚zâ‰¡1\frac{\partial g(z)}{\partial z}\equiv 1, so W1(t;ğ›ƒ)=ğ•1âˆ’1ğ(t). W_1(t;\boldsymbol{\beta}) = \boldsymbol{V}_1^{-1}\boldsymbol{B}(t).

Log Link

For the log link, g(Î¼)=log(Î¼), g(\mu) = \log(\mu),

âˆ‚g(z)âˆ‚z=1z,\frac{\partial g(z)}{\partial z} = \frac{1}{z},W1(t;ğ›ƒ)=ğ•1âˆ’1ğ(t){ğ(t)â€²ğ›ƒ}âˆ’1. W_1(t;\boldsymbol{\beta}) = \boldsymbol{V}_1^{-1}\boldsymbol{B}(t) \left\{\boldsymbol{B}(t)^\prime \boldsymbol{\beta}\right\}^{-1}.

Logit Link

For the logit link, g(Î¼)=log(Î¼1âˆ’Î¼), g(\mu) = \log\left(\frac{\mu}{1-\mu}\right), âˆ‚g(z)âˆ‚z=1z(1âˆ’z),\frac{\partial g(z)}{\partial z} = \frac{1}{z(1-z)}, W1(t;ğ›ƒ)=ğ•1âˆ’1ğ(t){ğ(t)â€²ğ›ƒ(1âˆ’ğ(t)â€²ğ›ƒ)}âˆ’1. W_1(t;\boldsymbol{\beta}) = \boldsymbol{V}_1^{-1}\boldsymbol{B}(t) \left\{\boldsymbol{B}(t)^\prime \boldsymbol{\beta} \left(1-\boldsymbol{B}(t)^\prime \boldsymbol{\beta}\right)\right\}^{-1}.
